template<typename V , typename F , typename S >

 Loops through segments of a container and call specified functor for all segments.

Detailed Description

There are several algorithms provided which walk through the points or segments of linestrings and polygons. They are called for_each_point, for_each_segment, after the standard library, and loop which is more adapted and of which the functor could break out if necessary. Of the for_each algorithms there is a const and a non-const version provided.

template<typename V , typename F , typename S >
bool geometry::loop ( const V &  v,
const F &  functor,
S &  state 
)

Loops through segments of a container and call specified functor for all segments.

for_each like implementation to:

  • walk over const segments of a linestring/polygon
  • be able to break out the loop (if the functor returns false)
  • have a const functor and keep state in separate state-object
  • we still keep the "functor" here so it might be a function or an object, at this place
  • in most algorithms the typename F::state_type is used; in those places it must be an object

Parameters:
v container (vector,list,deque) containing points
functor functor which is called at each const segment
state state, specified separately from the strategy functor
Returns:
false if the functor returns false, otherwise true
Template parameters:
  • V container type, for example a vector, linestring, linear_ring
  • F functor type, class or function, not modified by the algorithm
  • S state type, might be modified
Concepts
  • V
    • const_iterator begin()
    • const_iterator end()
    • value_type
  • F
    • if it is a function functor: bool function (const segment&, state&)
    • if it is a class functor: bool operator()(const segment&, state&) const
  • S
    • no specific requirements here, requirments given by F
Note:
Some algorithms from the Geometry Library, for example within, centroid, use this method.
Examples:
First example, using a class functor 
{
        // Class functor
        template <typename P>
        struct perimeter
        {
                struct summation
                {
                        double sum;
                        summation() : sum(0) {}
                };

                bool operator()(const geometry::segment<const P>& segment, summation& s) const
                {
                        std::cout << "from " << segment.first << " to " << segment.second << std::endl;
                        s.sum += geometry::distance(segment.first, segment.second);
                        return true;
                }
        };

        void example()
        {
                typedef geometry::point_xy<double> P;
                geometry::polygon<P> poly;
                geometry::from_wkt("POLYGON((0 0,0 7,4 2,2 0,0 0))", poly);
                perimeter<P>::summation peri;
                geometry::loop(poly.outer(), perimeter<P>(), peri);
                std::cout << "Perimeter: " << peri.sum << std::endl;
        }
} //:\\
Second example, using a function functor and latlong coordinates 
{
        struct summation
        {
                double sum;
                summation() : sum(0) {}
        };

        // Function functor
        template <typename P>
        bool perimeter(const geometry::segment<const P>& segment, summation& s)
        {
                std::cout << "from " << segment.first << " to " << segment.second << std::endl;
                s.sum += geometry::distance(segment.first, segment.second);
                return true;
        }

        void example()
        {
                typedef geometry::point_ll<geometry::degree, double> P;
                geometry::polygon<P> poly;
                geometry::from_wkt("POLYGON((-178.786 70.7853,177.476 71.2333,179.744 71.5733,-178.786 70.7853))", poly);
                summation peri;
                geometry::loop(poly.outer(), perimeter<P>, peri);
                std::cout << "Perimeter: " << peri.sum/1000.0 << " km" << std::endl;
        }
} //:\\
